text: On tap @ the Gingerman. This is a slightly cloudy looking one, reddish amber in the color and a small sidesticking head on the sides. Smells like a Jolly creation. Slightly wood tart, dryish yet berry fruity. Some white sugar hints. Mild but still quite nice. Thin and almost a little watery in the mouth while its soft on the prickling bubbles. Lots of tart wood in here. Red lingon berries, some salt. Theres a little bit of plum wine in this also. Decent and typically Jolly flavors, but a bit too anonymous to make it really interesting. 09.06.2015

Aroma is tart, caramel, citrus, barnyard, dusty, good. Appearance is copper, off white head, mostly hazy. Taste is tart, caramel, sour, woody, good. Mouthfeel is light to medium body, light crisp carbonation, dry tart aftertaste. Overall, this one is quite good.

Bottle in Seattle. Huge thanks to Julie who picked this up at JP when she was recently in Ann Arbor. Creamy lingering foam ring on a pretty rosy brown, rich malty body. Looks great. Dark cherry skin nose, with some developed funk and depth. Fairly sweet on nose too. Body is delicious and subtle, done with a great hand. Smooth character but flavors are wonderfully ruddy malt. Deep malt character leavened by a modest funk. Fantastic Flanders red. Wine grape and yeast finish. Light tannin. I really enjoy this.
Very dark brown, with thin white foam. Lots of cherry and red wine aromas, plus some oak. Flavor is more of the same, plus some balsamic vinegar. I enjoyed putting this into me.

Bottle from boxbeers.dk. Pours hazy reddish brown with a small slightly offwhite bubbly head. Aromas of caramel, rainsins, cherries, oak, leather, funk, light vinegary notes. Taste is oaky, tannic, cherries, caramel, raisins, vinegary. Quite nice!

UPDATED: MAR 4, 2017 375ml bottle. Tack Adam! Poured cloudy amber color with a thin white head. Sourish, funky aroma, some mild vinegar, green apples. Flavor has green apples, vinegar, tartness, red berries. Dry, sour finish. Interesting, flanders style.
No idea how it is Biere de Garde here, since it is really nice Flanders. Not very extreme in any side, but really well done.
Salty brett, light smoke, spicy, lactic and vinegar - medium intensity, caramel, toffee, dry white wine.

Bottle thanks to busprak mule service <3 Pours hazy reddish brown with a small slightly offwhite bubbly head. Aromas of caramel, rainsins, cherries, oak, leather, funk, light vinegary notes. Taste is oaky, tannic, cherries, caramel, raisins, vinegary. Quite nice!

From a bomber into snifter. Light brown, almost no head, clear. Nose is mild with a hint of funk, some caramel malt. Body is smooth, very little carbonation. I think the bottle was past prime but interesting none the less.
37,5 cl. bottle. Dark amber colour with an off-white head. Aroma and flavour of malt, fruit, peach and tartness.

(375ml bottle from boxbeers.dk) Pours a lightly hazed copper with a few stray white bubbles. Aroma is rather acidic and woody with moderate funk overall, notes of tart grapes and berries, lactic citrus, light acetic notes, oak, leather, soft caramel, orchard floor fruity funk, light spice? Flavour is tart but not heavily sour, grapes, light notes of cherry and tart cranberry, a touch of citrus, some slightly sweet caramel malt notes, increasing dryness from the oak, leather, a bit of earth, maybe some bittering hops, persistent tart grape, a little soap/solvent thing on the back end which is distracting. Lightly spicy Brett. Very dry, slightly bitter and tannic aftertaste Light to medium bodied with almost no carb. As the label says, feels like a Flanders red as much as a Biere de Garde, definitely on the sour side for the latter. Nice stuff despite the funny note towards the finish.
Caoba opaco y espuma de un marfil sucio. Aromas de fruta verde ácida, ciruela, uva,cuero, piel de naranja. En boca es igual con final seco.
Bottle. Sour fruity aroma with woody and bit spicy note. In taste tart cherry, peach, grapes flavour mix with brett, wood. Medium body, oily texture, soft carbonation, sour finish.

Bottle, pours cloudy tea color with white head that reduces to lacing after some minutes. A lot of small yeast particles are swimming inside. Aroma of cherries, plums, yoghurt, red wine and a hint of oak wood. Taste is very balanced with medium sourness some light sweetness and grapefruity bitterness in the finish. I wish I would have a bottle more to try how the growing sourness affects the impressions. Nice one.

Bottle. It pours hazy deep golden with a creamy white head. The aroma is dark fruits and some acetone. Dry berry notes. The flavor is sweet fruity with light acidic and acetone notes. Dry and malty finish.
Bottle. Aroma of citrus, caramel, overriped fruit and tart grapes. Wooden notes? Brett and lactic notes. Light sweet and moderate sour. Lingering acidicty. Light and watery. A Nice one. ..
#19 at bastardas blindtasting - 02.12.2016 - bottle from Joschi - Tasting notes: bready, sourdough, wood?, red fruits
Bottle. Reddish amber, light bodied. Drinks with a fizzy mouthfeel. Sour for sure. Sweet caramel underneath. (#6445, 12/3/2016)
Plenty of wood, berries and red fruits. Its bit acetic and sour, medium body, alcohol well hidden. Drinkable yet rich.

From bottle at Fermentoren Aarhus. Pours a clearish amber with a tiny off white head. Aroma has tons of oak, vanilla, leather, cherries, stone fruits, light caramel, funk. Taste is sour, stone fruity up front. Gets more dry and oaky, but finishes off juicy. Juicy body ass well and a rather low carbonation. Lovely! ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

375ml bottle. Cloudy, dark copperish colour with small, frothy, fading, off-white head. Vinous, fruity, minimally spicy and woody aroma, notes of morello cherry, hints of cinnamon, nutmeg, blue grapes. Taste is tart, dry, fruity, minimally spicy and woody, quite soapy, hints of morello cherry, pepper and dishwater; tangy finish.

Jolly Pumpkin know what the fuck theyre doing when it comes to dealing with funk. Biere de Mars pours red-brown and maintains a decent head considering its such an acidic beer. Dusty basement, leather, tobacco, and musty fruit aromas. The taste is equally wild and weird. Caramel, sour apple, balsamic vinegar, and subtle citrus. Sound weird? It is. Yet it totally works. Not as punchy as some Sours, but theres still a fair amount of vinegar-like acetic sharpness. Reminded me a lot of La Roja, and theres nothing wrong with that at all.

Bottle.

A- Tart, funky, acidic.

A- Reddish color, hazy liquid, off white head.

T- Funky, sour, tart, mild Brett, mineral water.

P- Medium body, average texture, average carbonation, tart finish.

O- Meh. Wasnt really fond of this. Certainly had its funk and sour notes, but not my thing.

Bottle. Hazy chestnut brown with a medium sized off white head with good retention, lace and regeneration. Strong juicy nose with lemon and minerals. Flavour has dark wood, tobacco, lemon, minerals and dark berries. Medium body, soft carbonation, medium sweet and light/medium sour. Long finish with minerals and dark wood. Not overdone, just crisp and flavourful.

375ml bottle (Alus Celle, Riga)
Pleasantish sourish aroma, some sweetish malts, Taste similar, woody sourish aspects. Yucky soapy taste. Not what I expect from JP at all. Way too much soap to enjoy this.

375ml bottle (thanks FatPhil). Clear dark amber color. Tiny to almost no head. Acidic, lemon, fruity, balsamico in aroma. Acidic, sharp, fruity, lemon juice and balsamico in taste. Balsamico in aftertaste. There is level of enjoyment, but it is too sharp for me. Drinkable, but naah.

Bottle (shared by fatphil, thanks). Pours dark amber. Aroma is sweet, sour, medicinal, sugar. Flavor is sweet and sour, fruits, caramel, brett, oak. Feels bit watery. Finish has some bitterness. Overall: good.

Hazy amber color with off-white head that fizzes away completely. Aroma is sweet and tart with a slight acetic note, some tart fruits and a bit of sugar. Taste starts tart and yeasty with some sugar in the background, light vinegar and yeast notes. Medium body with low carbonation, quite dry mouthfeel. Quite interesting, more in the direction of a flanders red than a biere de garde.
clear dark coppar colour with a small delicate head. Tart berries, basement, vinegar in the aroma. Dry and tart. Decent American sour

Pours a murky reddish brown from the bottle with bubbly off-white head. Aroma of funky yeast, dark fruit, lactic acidity, and musty earth. Taste is more of the lactic and the fruit with a nice funky, dry finish. Solid American sour red.
Bottle from Kihoskh. Murky amber pour with a decent fluffy head. Notes of leather, oak, tart, vanilla, red berries, tannins, cranberries and some funk. Gewd!
For the price I paid for a draft of this beer it should have been phenomenal.
Bottle.Muddy orange colour with small head.Aroma of berries and fruits tart most like also yeast,nice sour with hint of barnyard and vinagar also cherris and raspberrys really nice fruity beer.
Aroma is cherries/raspberries, mild funk and a hint of vinegar. The flavor is berries, fruit, malts, earthy, light citrus/orange and a tart/slightly sweet finish.
Bottle. Pours a reddish copper. Aroma and taste are sour funk, dark cherries, and fig.

2013 bottle thanks to Roger. Remarkably clear amber pour with creamy head. Nice nose of caramel, toast, oak, and lemon funk. Basically a bretted amber. Moderately tart, drying finish. Medium body, average carbonation. Overall: very nice.
Bottle poured into a pint glass. Aroma is citrus and barnyard. Taste is pleasantly sour. Very drinkable.
(bottle) clear, bright amber colour with a small beige head; aroma of wood, sourness, spice; moderately sour, bit spicy, refreshing flavour with a medium long, medium strong sour finish
bottle 2/12/16 blend 01 ramata velata piatta leggere note acetiche legno secca buona acidita lieve idrocarburi

Bottle. Wild yeast, cherries and oak in the aroma. Taste is sour fruits, oak, chestnuts, plums, a more classic Flanders red (as opposed to the more vinegary brown) but with some funk and lemon as well. Mild carbonation. Really, really good.
Pours an amber/brown with a thin white head. Aroma is lactic acid, fruit, and herbal and spice notes. Flavor is similar. This is pretty sour. Pretty good.
750ml bottle. Murky orange shade. Finger of head. Notes of grape, green apple, citrus, deep earthiness and oak. Dry and slightly sour taste. Nicely joined up. Seems like a good example of this style.
Clear red copper pour with a white head. Aroma is earthy funk, wood, and some tart cherry. Taste is funk, earth, wood, berry skin, and faint apple cider vinegar. Dry finish. Light body.

Clear deep amber with a thin off white bubbly head that recedes a little fast. Earthy funky and peppery nose full of white pepper, lactic and bretty combined funk, earthy Amber brine and something almost like Colby jack cheese. Funky earthy flavor with a slightly tart Amber malt, gentle citrus fruitiness, light sour, and some barrel notes. Earthy and peppery and slightly red-berry flavored throughout.
2016-2-12 bottle, the yeast seemed too spontaneous ferment, good pucker factor, no malt, little body, have had better Flanders, but this was enjoyable.

There have been only two beers Ive had that I took two sips of and poured down the sink. This, sadly, was one. Average smell and appearance still didnt prepare me for way-too-fruity and sour flavor that was unpalatable to me. Didnt get any taste of the oak barreling at all. After taste wasnt any better. Its the first Jolly Pumpkin that lve had after being intrigued for a while. May be a while before I stick my toe back into the water.

On tap at Jolly Pumpkin in Detroit pours a muddy brownish amber with basically no head. Nose is a mix of dark fruit, some dried fruit, a little vinegar, some wood pulp. Flavor is tart with acid and underipened fruit, raisins, dates, some apricot too, light tobacco notes, some cooked greens, some neutral oak. Dry finish.

Bottle from Spec's. Hazy, almost muddy, reddish-brown with a very tiny off-whitish head. Aroma of sour cherry, musty wood, and caramel. Taste is sour and woody. Slick, slightly dry, and medium bodied. Good.

UPDATED: MAY 13, 2016 Draft at Bru Craft. Cloudy chestnut brown pour that started with a solid top of soft khaki foam. Big tannic brown fruit sour. Prunes. Sour cherries. Browned peaches. Dried lemons, apricots and figs. Pineapples. Lots of drying oak tannins but still sharply tart.
Clouded brown with a red tint. Sticky head. Sour aroma and very sour flavor with notes of citrus fruit with a cool, light body. Well made. Good balance and very easy to continually enjoy.

Tap at Vinsettas garage. Pours hazy copper, off white head. Aroma is fig, dark cherry, oak, sour funk. Amazing. Flavor is dark cherries, sour funk, fig, some. Toffee, slightly woody. It has a lot going on. A hop bitterness in the finish. Awesome.

Ölföreningen 2015. Flaska, 2012 vintage. Smak och doft av trä, körsbär, ek, jord, toner av hallon och frysta jordgubbar, karamell med toner av vinäger. Fruktig, något syrlig, stor sötma, bra balans mellan smakerna. Mycket gott!
Tasting at MattsCloudy amber color with no head. Aroma of hazelnut, a bit sour and fruity, nice apricot profile. Sour and fruity, with nice astringency, and mild funky touch.Very good.

Flaska från demolenbeershop drucken med ölgörningen. 2012 vintage. Större kropp och mer sötma än ett genomsnittsöl från JP som funkar väldigt bra med laktosyrligheten som är bryggeriets hussmak. Sötman lyfter verkligen smakerna och höjer fuktigheten, honungsmjuk vinäger, aprikos, körsbär- och plommon kärnor, kastanjer. riktigt gott.
Amber, chestnut with a small white head. Aroma is light malt, oak, balsamic vinegar, sour yeast. Light bodied, oily texture, finish is light medium sour with light hop bitterness.

Bottle from Gourmet Haus Staudt in Redwood City, CA. Aroma is mild musty things, animal horns, stone fruits, dried apricots, underripe cherries. Taste is tart underripe cherries, fermented strawberries / stone fruits and bone dry, oakiness. The pre-cursor to all things Prairie Artisan Ales but not as wild.
bottle. Golden with two finger head. All the big JP sour funk youd expect. Base beer has a lightly bitter oakiness. Wonderfully complex and delicious.
Sampled at Great American Beer Festival 9/24/15. Nutty malts, dark fruits, funky yeast and mild sour notes. Nicely done overall.

750 ml bottle shared by Bruce. Murky deep amber with a fair off-white head. Tangy and funky, fruity, a lightly smoky note, light wood, bread, bread crust, a touch spicy. Medium body, medium-low carbonation. Nice bread and biscuit malt, moderately funky, light sourness, lightly spicy; dry with moderate sourness, fair bitterness with a bread crust and lightly funky finish.
The oak aging is very prominent. Looks really good poured in the glass. Real light aroma.

750mL bottle, pours a cloudy dark orangey brown with a small white head. Aroma brings out loads of oak, light tartness, and light wild yeast. Flavour is complex, with loads of oak, light tartness like a Flanders Red, and some wild yeast. Super complex, with a lovely tartness and oakiness. An archetype for Biere de Gardes out there. Fantastic.

750 mL from Mile High. This is a brilliant dark amber with a long lasting white head. The aroma is funky with notes of baking spices, dark fruits, chestnuts and acidity. The palate is medium full and soft in the mouth. Carbonation is assertive. There are flavors of wool, goats, toffee, nuts, vinaigrette, berries, and bread. Finish is bone dry. Needless to say, Jolly Pumpkin has been and continues to master sour beer.
A very interesting mix of fruit, tartness, funk and malt. No real hop presence. Definitely has that house JP flavor, but thats ok too. Slightly overcarbonated, but good stuff.

The beer pours a hazy orange color with an enormous off-white head that fades slowly. The aroma blends acidity, sour fruit, and some low-level caramel malts. The taste is mildly sour and a touch sweet with a slightly oak flavor alongside some sour fruit notes. The palate fuses a medium body, slick texture, and a soft carbonation.

Bottle 750ml @ Jolly Pumpkin Cafe & Brewery, Ann Arbor, MI
Pours hazy amber with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt, caramel, yeast, funk and citrus. Taste is medium sweet, light bitter and light sour with a long slightly dry, fruity, funky and citrus finish. Body is light to medium, texture is thin to oily, carbonation is soft.

Bottle, 75cl, at Jolly Pumpkin, Ann Arbor. A hazy amber colored beer with a small, off-white head. The aroma is tad weak I think, with dried fruit notes, lemon juice, some leathery, barnyard funk and a hint of fruit caramel. Its medium bodied and dry on the palate, quite effervescent, with flavors of dried fruit, lemon juice and funk. Grapefruit bitter. Lasting finish. Needs some temperature this one, but even then its not more than good. 150614

Brown pour, amber hue, quick off white head. Nose is a hint of cherries, wood, funky yeast. Somewhat sour. Middle is soft leather, plums, sweet malt, and light toffee. Finish is sour and refreshing. Try this one, preferably with food (Mild Italian sausage, baked beans and fresh Roma tomatoes for me.)

Very cloudy orange brown pour with white corona of head. Cottony sweet tart aroma, apple and florals with a hint of lactose, straightforward. Very soft carbonation, tingly mouthfeel - detectable sour, crisp dry finish. Flavor of cracked pepper, lots of lemon and apple, barnyard funk, earthy malt. Nice light bodied sour that doesnt overdo it.

750ml bottle, pours amber, chestnut with a small white head. Aroma is light malt, oak, balsamic vinegar, sour yeast. Light bodied, oily texture, finish is light medium sour with light hop bitterness. Carbonation is soft. Not had a Brett beer quite like this and its very drinkable.

Bottle, batch 281/283, enjoyed one year after bottling. Pours maroon, with a finger thick creamy head. Aroma is balsamic vinegar, berries, nuts, and wooden barrels, as well as some bretty funk. Medium body, with soft to none carbonation. Flavour is tart with balsamic vinegar, wooden barrels, tannins and leather, as well as forest berries. Lingering tart, funky finish with fruity notes.
Slight funky grainy aroma, tons of yeast. Flavor is acidic and sour, quickly changing to strike hop flavor, and then finishing dry and bready. Excellent, strong flavour but easy to drink.
Draft @ ABC: Poured orange brown. Aroma is filled with nice fruit and tart spice. Taste is a mellow taste is woodsy tart fruitiness.

Served on tap at Milkeller. Hazy dark red Amber color with a large white head. Strong fruit and citrus aroma. Very fruity and sweet flavor. Medium body with fizz throughout.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap, poured into a balloon snifter. The aroma is oak and sour cherry with a warm bake spice and pie crust, along with some caramel adding to the mix late. The beer pours a murky amber with a thick, white soap head that has a moderate light retention and only a light, runny lace. The taste is a balance between medium sweet and sour with a slightly less potent (although still present) bitter; it has a nice overall roundedness. The beer is oily with a soft fizz and a medium body. The taste is dry, sweet, tart plums, cherries, and a hint of citrus with a light woody smoke, light caramel, and a swallow that has a zesty, zippy clean quality with a bright toffee flourish. It finishes clean with a resinous character and a taste of light, sour citrus, candy apple, candy corn, and a dry rye bread which lasts only a short time leaving just a touch in the aftertaste.
Dark clear red color with close to no foam. Light sour smell. The taste is sweetish, sour a tiny bit bitter. A quite fitting combination. Nice beer with a satisfying aftertaste.

Hazy amber color with hardly any head. Aroma is nice oak tannins, bretty, fruity, balance between gummy bears and spicy soy sauce. Taste is fruity, apples, oak, smooth carbonation, slightly sour finish. Beautiful. Not too intense but beautiful!
Tap @ Bridge Tap House & Wine Bar - St. Louis: Mild sour ale with a small oak influence. Not too crazy with the pH. Bitter tastes.

Tap at Jolly Pumpkin Detroit. Had this a couple times in bottle too but just never rated for some reason. Hazy copper pour with a 1 finger head that fades slowly to a film and leaves great lacing. Huge oaky and tannic aroma with some red fruit and light brett funk. Light sourness in the taste. Big red wine, oak, and vinegar with some vanilla and light floral/cotton funk. Very smooth. Good stuff.

Draft at the Bridge. Pours golden with a white head. Leaves a fair amount of lacing in the glass. I cant say im getting much on the nose. Big oak notes on the nose. Solid hop notes on the tongue. Finishes clean. Jolly pumpkin doesnt do little beers and this is no exception.
Remember when you dared your friend to stuff like 4 sour warheads in his mouth in middle school? Me neither. But this is what I always figured that was like for him except good.

Pours a super hazy copper with a small white head that leaves plenty of lacing. Nose is of fruits, oak and surprisingly light on the vinegar (the characteristic Jolly Pumpkin twang I mean). Taste is lightly tart and fruity. A lot of oak. Refreshing acidity. Body is medium, carbonation moderately light and mouthfeel is tannic and oaky (should have said "vinous" simply). Overall a really nice "bière de garde", tweaked by Jolly Pumpkin but in a good way and really drinkable.

Fra flaske på Mandag i annen, Cardinal mars-15, rett etter Calabasa Boreal: nypusset kobber med kort hvitt skum. Kanksje litt surere enn foregående, men fortsatt like lett å helle innpå. God karbonering, elegant slank munnfylde med sursyrlig ettersmak. Stikkelsbær, kirsebær og maltsødme. Iflg Sigmund så tilsetter JP alle sine øl litt av deres egen brettanomyceskultur.
Shared bottle at Cardinal (mandag i annen). Pours clear amber with big off-white head. Aroma of white wine, vinegar, caramel. Taste sour, but not extreme. Malty caramel and cherries.

Superbe robe ambrée translucide avec une fine toile blanche sur le dessus. De fines bulles se dégagent sans pour autant créer une trop grosse effervescence. Arômes de bretts, citron, et caramel doux. En bouche, cest très funky. Des saveurs de caramel et épices se dévoilent au milieu de ce party de levures sauvages acidulées. La finale est citronnée et amère avec une pointe caramélisée. Le corps est mince, soyeux et doux. Excellente bière de JP encore une fois.

750 ml bottle, Cardinal Pub & Bar, Stavanger. "French Style Stock Ale - Ale Aged in Oak Barrels". ABV is 7%. Hazy amber to brownish colour, large off-white head. Strong aroma of farmhouse. horse blanket, lemons, oak and apple cider vinegar. Medium sour flavour with lemony and oaky notes, fairly distinct and peppery hops in the finish. "Beware the ides of March!"
Bottle 9.4fl.oz. White head dying. Hazy red color. Aroma is wine, oak, sherry, roses. Taste is sour. Party in brown barrels resulting in winey beer.

Butelka 75cl. 
OCZY : piwo jest przejrzyste o kolorze jasnym z odcieniami brązu i brudnej pomarańczy. Piana mala i byle jaka. Kolor brudnej bieli. Ogólnie piwo jest brzydkie ale za to przejrzyste. 

NOS : piana szybko opadła i trudno ja z powrotem wzburzyć co nie pomaga wydobyć intensywne aromaty. Wyczuwam lekka tarte i susz owocowy o nutach jabłka, gruszki i delikatnie wygotowanych wiśni. W zapachu jest również drewno i delikatnie gozdzki. Do tego czarna porzeczka. 

USTA : piwo jest wodniste o niskim nasyceniu o drobnych bąbelkach. Całkiem przyjemne w ustach i bardzo łatwe w piciu. 
Smak piwa nie jest super intensywny ale świetnie ułożony. Cechuje to piwo delikatna i przyjemna kwaśność i cierpkość o nutach zielonego jabłka i drewna. Główne nuty to tarta i gotowane wyżej wymienione owoce. Alkohol jest całkowicie ukryty i ma się wrażenie pić delikatnie sfermentowany kompot z suszu. Chmiele nie graja wielkiej roli w tym piwie, dodają ziołowych niuansów. Posmak jest długi ale delikatny o nutach owocowych i cierpkich. 

ODCZUCIA : pomimo, że piwo nie jest uber intensywne (na co cena tego piwa sugeruje) ale nie mogę się przyczepić do super pijalności i przyjemności z subtelności tego piwa. Profil kwaskowaty jest pod mój gust. Ja lubię. 

OCENA : 
smak : 6/10
pijalność : 9/10
styl : +2

Poured from bottle, pours a murky brown with a thin off white head, the aroma is very tart and sour on the nose with some fruit coming trough too, the flavor has the Brett on the front end with a tart and fruity finish with some oak and vanilla as well. really tasty, wish this wasnt $16 or else I would buy it more often.

Bottle: Murky brown, almost swamp watery with a slightly jaundice & beige-tinted cap that fizzles quickly to a thin collar. Ugly duckling. Lovely tart aroma filled with apple skins, cherry skins, vinegar, drying oak staves, & a tangy, lactic sourness. Pungent, yet inviting. Nice back-end cork & wet hay funk. Each sip has a nice bite of acidic sourness out of the gate with a huge mountain of tangy, sharp, tannic woody notes alongside it. Apple, red grape, acetic sourness & vinegar, moderate vinousness, damp cellar floor funk, musty floral tones, all leading into an uber-dry & modestly funky finish. Corky, fruity, acidic, acetic, lactic, tangy, tart, tannic, dry, lovely. Great stuff.

UPDATED: JAN 6, 2015 Bretty caramel aroma, funk, hay, grains, barnyard. Taste upfront is very well balanced tartness which turns into dry brett barnyard and some refreshing floral peach like notes. Lemony with some light brett and funk.

Poured from bomber into tulip. This was an interesting beer for sure. A tart aroma gives way to an effervescent beer that is mild In flavor but still quite complex. It's earthy with a tinge of sourness. Honestly, I could have taken even more sourness in this. The oak comes through big time, working very well in the beginning and middle of the taste, but getting a little overbearing in the finish. That combined with a baking soda like bitterness in the finish downgrades this a bit for me. Still good.
i liked it a lot, very tart, bretty, a lot like norma. Tons of nuances and flavors, brett finish. Very very nice.

Au nez, on sent bcp l'acidité, le chêne et le malt. En bouche, il y a une belle acidité mélangé avec un goût prononcé de bois. C'est râpeux sur les côtés de la langue. La finale laisse un goût râpeux sur la langue nous rappelant le fut de chêne. Beau mélange de garde et de sûr!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle at Schouskjelleren, october 17th 2014. Murky brown body with a small beige head. Fruity tart aroma, berries, caramel. Taste of oak, funky and bretty with a good amount of malt sweetness, lemons and berries. Not as sour as many Jolly Pumpkins but still recognisable, herbal funky finish. Really pleasant.

75cl bottle. It pours a hazy dark amber ruby-ish color with a small off-white head. Aroma is funky, musty, lemony, woody with some tart cherries and wine vinegar. Taste is mildly sweet with more cherries, and tart with funky lemon tanginess. Body is medium with lively carbonation. Overall, hard to get it wrong for JP it looks like.

Bottle from Corvallis Brew Supply, Corvallis. Pours a slightly cloudy golden color, lots of head. Aroma is dry and stiff, attenuated yeast driven character, a wee but of funk. Body is arch and dry, with a sharp doughiness, finishing crisply. This is top notch stuff.

Bottle bought @ bierkompass.de. Pours hazy goldenish reddish brown with a rather small frothy and bubbly beige head that leaves a small trace on the glass while dissipating. Smell is funky, slightly malty and tiny fruity with dark bread, cereal, lemon juice, raisins, cherry pits, leather, moist wood, soil, barnyard, hay, liquorice root, black pepper corns, kumquats and lemon zest. Taste is sour, funky, slightly malty and slightly fruity with dark bread, caramel, cereal, lemon juice, unripe grapes, sour cherries, black currants, moist wood, barnyard, leather, hay, soil, lemon zest and hints of balsamic vinegar. Mouthfeel is dry, tart, vinous and light to medium bodied. Finish is sour, funky, slightly malty and tiny fruity with dark bread, cereal, lemon juice, unripe grapes, sour cherries, moist wood, moist soil, barnyard, hay, leather, lemon zest and hints of balsamic vinegar. Tasty sour amber saison / flemish red hybrid

750 ml bottle into tulip glass; Blend 1, bottled 3/1/2011.  Pours lightly hazy reddish copper color with a 1-2 finger foamy off white head with good retention, that reduces to a thin cap that lingers.  Light spotty lacing clings on the glass.  Aromas of big tart cherry, sour apple, raisin, caramel, clove, pepper, toast, oak, hay, leather, red wine, grass, funk, vinegar, and earthy yeast spiciness.  Incredible aromas with great complexity and balance of fruity/spicy yeast notes with moderate malt balance and barrel character.  Taste of tart cherry, sour apple, raisin, caramel, pepper, clove, toast, oak, hay, leather, red wine, grass, vinegar, funk, and earthy yeast spiciness.  Moderate fruity tartness on the finish; with lingering notes of tart fruits, caramel, clove, pepper, toast, hay, grass, oak, leather, red wine, vinegar, and yeast earthiness on the finish for a good bit.  Fantastic complexity and balance of fruity/spicy esters with moderate barrel character and malt balance; with a great tartness/sweetness balance and no cloying flavors after the finish.  Medium carbonation and body; with a creamy, slick, and moderately acidic mouthfeel that is nice.  Alcohol is very well hidden with hardly any warming noticed after the finish.  Overall this is an incredible wild Biere de Garde style!  All around great complexity and balance of flavors; and very smooth to sip on with moderate acidity.  An extremely enjoyable offering.

Bottle thanks to GT.  Pours a hazy dense orange brown with a thin white head. Oaky wine like aroma. Dry sour flavor.  Thick creamy vanilla oak throughout. Very tart finish. Very refreshing on a 100 degree humid day in DC.

Draft at THE FESTIVAL with Andrew. Pours a hazy amber body with nice white lacing. Aroma is funk, sour cherry, and other tart fruit. Mouthfeel is tart, puckering and full with notes of sour, tart cherries, funky JP signature, and some fruit.
Draft at festival, acidic tartness, JP funkiness, great funk. Another winner from jolly pumpkin

750ml bottle from Knightly Spirits (I think).  Brown pour with a smallish light tan head.  Aroma of vinegar, dark fruit, green apple, cherry and oak.  Tastes follow suit with sour, light spice, earthy, green grape, brett.  Nice funky tone overall.  Finishes a light dry with a buttery medium texture and good fizz. Seemed a little weak on first sip, but enjoyed it more and more over the bottle. Very nice. Something I probably wouldnt have appreciated a couple years ago.

Ar: Hint of caramel, funk, a little metallic - some clean apple, too
Ap: Cloudy amber - small off-white head with a ring of lacing.
T: Sour and a touch malty - cherry, plum, some sweetness - strongly sour finish with big fruit notes and some higher alcohols.
P: Medium body with medium-high carbonation - finish is dry.
O: The most sour biere de garde Ive ever had, but Im enjoying it - mixes the typical deep malt flavor with some nice fruit and sourness.
Golden brown.  No head.  Cherries and brown sugar with woody notes.  Mostly tart, slightly cherryish, with a woody finish.  Doesnt really bring the sugars and complexity the nose promised.

bottle from knightly. rich dark earthy brown. scattered lace. aroma ripe with brettanomyces, pulverized cherry pits, ripe mamey, black cherries. drinkable lush palate. flavors of fun fungus, black raspberry, and planks of wood. fun and highly drinkable stuff as usual. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Another sample I tried yesterday forced me to bring a bottle home. This shames the Grand Reserve. Dark amber with a very thick white head. Head stuck around until the end, awesome. Very heavy in the yeast and oak department in the nose, some citrus zest. Flavor is very lemon zest heavy, oak, must, and a bit of herbs/grass. Finishes very tart for pumpkin, lots of carbonation. Very nice.

Pours a murky copper color with a nice off white head that fades to a collar. Aroma is funk, with some oak and vanilla hints and a slight fruity hint that I cant fully describe. Taste is FANTASTIC! Oaky hints with some funk and just the right hit of sourness with a dry finish, some slight sour cherry hints.. this beer is amazing
Amber brown color. Slightly cloudy with average head. Modest oak in aroma and taste. More funky sour taste than most other Jolly Pumpkin ales that I have tried.

Bottled 75cl. Murky deep copper with a huge quick diminishing bubbly light beige head. Deeply inviting brett accented aroma with raisins, oak, dandelion, oxidized lemon peel, candied apricot, caramel and sage emerging. Good balance. Creamy palate. Some acidity. Medium bodied. A tad too much carbonation. Complex. Nice vanilla presence on the swallow, introducing a lingering caramel component in the finish which is dryish, reminiscent of dandelion and sage.

Bottle at Erzbierschof. Pours a cloudy amber with a thin off white head. Smells of light apricot, Brett, horse blanket, and a hint of grass. Tastes of a large sour, medium sweetness, and mild bitter. Texture is creamy, carbonation is soft, finish is tart and sweet. A beautiful beer.

From notes.  First reviewed 11/19/2011.  Poured from a 750 mL bottle into a tulip.

Biere de Mars pours a hazy apple cider bronze color with a medium tan head that eventually fades to a ring around the edge of the glass. No real lacing to speak of.

The aroma is mostly sour, with a soft leather and musty funk. Caramel malt and dried dark fruits, mostly cherries, control the aroma with an oak back.

A soft caramel sweetness starts out before the lactic sourness takes over. Cherry plum notes remind me of an Oude Bruin. Some oak, vanilla, and spice come in toward the middle of the sip, with some lemon zest and general tartness to finish it off. 

The body of Biere de Mars is a little bit fuller than I expect from a sour. The oak dries out and lightens the back end, but the body is still on the full side. The feel is sour, mostly lactic, that causes some salivation. The carbonation is on the light side and fades over the course of the glass. 

Jolly Pumpkin makes quite a few solid sours, and this falls in the upper tier of their beers. Only the Biere de Mars Grand Reserve can really compete in my mind.

Dont know how I havent rated this, but here goes.  Pours a deep dark amber brown with thick tan head, lots of lacing.  Aroma is tart from the go, with a nice roasted malt backbone, floral yeast, and dried dark and tart fruits.  Flavor matches well and takes it home.  Never disappointed with JP.

Tap at GTMW.  Burgundy brown, thin head that clings to the sides of the glass.  Aggressively sour, this is awesome.  Has some smooth malt tones, but completely awash in Brett tanginess.  Cherry, lemon, lime, orange.  Wow.

sample from 750 bottle at the CASK Group Brew in Jacksonville, Feb 25, 2012.   Red-amber beer with a yeasty, sour aroma.   Flavor was strongly sour, malty with some funk.  Notes of cherry and plum.  Pretty good.

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2012 [4134-20111119] 1pt9.4floz bottle. Mild grainy light flora yeast aroma. Slightly hazy, red amber body with a medium-lasting creamy off-white head. Sour fruity yeast malt flavour. Medium-full body. Nice blend. (6/3/8/4/14) 3.5
(@ Rudys Sourfest 2011)

[4741B-20120818] 1pt9.4floz bottle. Toasty yeast aroma. Slightly hazy, orange brown body with a quick foamy white head. Sour yeast and light lemon drops in the flavour. Medium body is pretty sour. Tasty. (6/3/8/4/15) 3.6
(@ Campground Brewdown 2012, Millmont, PA)

Refrigerated bottle poured into a trappist glass.  Pours translucent dark brown, amber highlights with couple finger tan head that disspates fairly quickly.  A little lacing, medium body, medium carbonation, and signature jolly pumpkin sour aroma.  Taste is sour apple, hint of sour cherry, and earthy sourness.
75cl, Blend 2, American brew, thx to Jeppe!, complex sour brew, malty/sour and slightly woody/vinous, easy to drink, balanced, hazy, small head, good brew, yet expensive!

2011-11-19. Hazy dark amber body with a nice creamy small beige head. 3+ Very lightly funky, lemon notes, light floral character as it warms up. Modest sourness up front grows a lot towards the finish, good amount of hoppy bitterness, but of grapefruit and dried fruit character. 7+ Average palate. Subtle, very drinkable, solid. Some of the subtleties are lost on me today. Bottle dated 3/8/2011, shared at Rudolfs Sourfest 2011"... and then halfway, its all like Sour Bitches!"

Bottle.  Wow I was not expecting such a sour beer.  Hazy dark red brown, with thin off-white head.  Tons of tart apple, tart cherry, some lactic acid, juicy red fruit, vinegar, light caramel, light bread, some funk, and herbal grassiness.  Damn this is tasty.

750ml Bottle:  Aroma of tart fruit, Brett, oak, slight dried fruit, malt, and red wine.  Poured deep amber in color with a medium-sized, creamy, dense, off-white head that diminished but lasted throughout.  Hazy.  Sparkling.  Flavor is light to medium sweet and lightly tart.  Tastes of malt, oak, light Brett, slight tart fruit, grapes, vinous, slight funk, light caramel, and slight spice.  Medium body.  Slightly tingly, then slightly sticky, and lightly dry texture.  Average carbonation.  Medium sweet, slightly tart, malt, caramel, slight Brett, dark ripe fruit finish is lightly dry.

Denmark, Ulfborg tasting with J&C. Dark amber color, with small head. Sweet malty aroma with lots of caramel, and a vinous touch. Flavour reminds me of Flemish sour, which is the type of sourne3ss I erally enjoy. Very vinous, still maintains its malty background. Lead to a ncie dry finish. Lovely.

Bottle purchased at the Jolly Pumpkin Old Mission location.  A murky brown/mahogany in color.  There is a half fingers worth of white head that has good retention.  Really solid nose on this, lemon, cherry throat lozenge, some spice, and a touch of earthiness.  Body is a little lighter than I would like, but it has good carbonation and a long finish.  There is some nice acidity on the finish.  One of the better Jolly Pumpkin offerings,  the wild yeast has taken a nice hold of this and given a nice tart kick.

Thanks to djrn2 for sending me this beer off my wants list. Batch 256.

The beer pours a dark brown color with an off-white head. The aroma is very nice. I get a lot of dark fruit, with some plums and cherries standing out the most. I also get some caramel malt. 

The flavor is full of tart apples and tart cherries, as well as some yeast and a little bit of funk. The toffee malt adds a touch of sweetness to the flavor profile, which goes well with the tart fruit notes. Overall, a little more sour than I expected it to be. Very enjoyable overall.

Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.
Shared bottle, bottle is 472/473.  Poured with no head. Aroma is slightly sour, with notes of wild yeast, earthy hop notes. Flavor is sour fruit notes. This one is pretty tart, pretty enjoyable.

Bottle courtesy of jale. Served in a Bruery tulip.

Pours a muddy brown color with a bit of a copper-crimson hue to it. Thin off-white head and some light lacing on the way down. Thin collar. Nose carries a good dose of lactic acid with a touch of acetic character in the background. Mild funk and a solid base of bread-crust malt. Flavor is acidic and a nice tartness and a very light cherry character. Light malt. Light to medium body with moderate carbonation and a good sour kick in the finish. Well done.

drank at hill farmstead saison festival. copper, red tint, small and disappearing white head.aromas of oak, medicine, bubblegum. taste of cherries, acidity, some pepper. average carbonation light to medium body.
Bottle at Hill Farmstead.  Murky brown color, beige head, good lacing. Aroma of sour and earthy citrus. Taste is softly sour summer fruits, and earth. Nice.

Rating # 2300!  750 mL bottle from Leukens Dunedin.  Pours a hazy maple syrup color with orange highlights.  Nose is tart vinous fruit, oak, red wine, vinegar, and vague hints of sweetness behind the tart qualities.  Flavor starts off with some light malts quickly assaulted by the oak, vinegar, yeast, and vinous fruit.  Light to medium in body and very enjoyable for a style I do not particularly care for.  Finish leaves with some oaky tartness and not much of that trademark JP Michigan yeast.  Outstanding bier de garde.

750ml Bottle. Opaque Amber with off white head. Retained Somewhat. Light, funky, spices, brett, green apple, oak, light aroma from dark malts and grain. Light-med body, sourness is light on the palate giving the perception of a lighter beer, but also more carbonated than an above moderate level. Some cherries showcased. Finish is satisfying, sourness is balanced by light deep malts and is semi sweet sour.

Bottle thanks to Timbo and April, thanks 
Appearance: Slightly hazy amber with a medium sized off-white head and good lacing 
Aroma: Sourness and cherries 
Taste: Tart fruits and oak 
Very nice. Tim wouldnt give up until I finally had a decent beer from JP, thanks.

750 shared by Craig, thanks man. Pours a brown color fairly opaque with a medium white head. A tart and sweet nose of oak and brown sugar and some spices. The flavor is wonderful; very unusual, sweet funkiness, almost vinous, certainly a different brew, some sweet malts. Light breadiness.Awesome.
750 ml bottle.  Amberish color with a beautiful funky earthy sour aroma and taste.  This is one great funky beer.

From notes:

Pours a very dark ruby/chestnut brown color that appears completely opaque in the glass with sligh mahogany edges and a two finger frothy beige head. Very good retention, slowly fading into a lasting cap that leaves chunks of soapy lacing behind.

Funky earthy aroma with a prominent barrel character as well as some bret, citrus fruit and zesty spice. Lots of earthy oak/wood as well as some coriander and citrus rind.

Full chewy body with a slightly creamy texture as well as some soft carbonation up front and a good bit of dry funk. Slightly tart without being acidic. Nice dry Bret presence along with a wrong barrel character and malt backbone. Hints of earhy oak, dry Bret and other bugs,vanilla and citrus peel. Dry finish. Complex, refreshing and very easy to drink. One of my favorite beers from JP.
Cloudy amber with a small creamy white head. Aroma is brett, sour, spices, cinnamon. Medium body with average carbonation. Flavours are sour, spicy, earthy. Well done, would have again and again...
On tap at Jolly Pumpkin and had from a bottle at Dark Lord Day aged for 3 years. Not overly sour with some dark fruits coming through. Overall really well done. Would have again.

Had this one on tap at JP in A2 and had from a bottle at DLD aged for 3 years I believe. It tastes sweet and sour I would say with a nice hazy light yellow colour. Very tasty beer, good souriness but nothing too sour. Very good offering

750mL at Redlight Redlight. Poured an opaque-ish mahogany with a thin, creme tan head leaving nice lacing behind. Aroma of balsamic vinegar, Rodenbach reminiscent oak and dark cherries, Flemish red characters all the way: spicy oak, spicy balsamic, sweet cherries, and even a few funky notes that remind me of framboise lambic and raspberry seeds. Taste is beautiful, sourness in check, no Rodenbach sweetness or  heavy acetic sourness. Some cinnamon spice, spicy vinegar, spicy oak, lemon, tart citrus, black cherries, pinot grape skins come to balance. Extremely soft mouthfeel. Lots of vinous qualities abounding. What an accomplishment.

Poured from a bottle into into a brandy snifter. Appearance is a hazy brown with a beige head that dissipates quickly. Aroma is a bit sour with notes of fig, alcohol, green apples, and tart cherries. Taste is much like the aroma. This is an absolutely wonderful beer that I would recommend to anybody that likes great beer. This one has everything.
Fresh light-malted barley aroma.  Light copper and fairly clear (for JP).  Light apple notes on the flavor.  Would like to try another bottle.
sampled at MBGSF10 - dark orange pour, huge sour tart notes/ lactic and fruity. Creamy body, puckering, juicy. touch of funk. wonderful.

A: snifter. pours a straight opaque mahogany. nice medium khaki colored head. great retention and lacing.

S: tons of coconut, lemon zest, big sour nose. some blood oranges. some tropical fruit, papaya, mango.

T: nice tropical fruit flavors, hints of papaya, coconut, and a dash of mango. big time sours in this. absolutely delicious. great malt, but the barrel aging in outstanding.

M: higher carbonation level, bu fits the beer. great palate all over this one. very unique mouthfeel. velvety.

D: I could probably drink anything from JP for the rest of my life, amazing palate characteristics form from their barrels. try to get this one....it is phenomenal.

Sampled at GTMW 2010 - Pours dark amber with a small bubbly off-white head. Funky, skunky nose with sour citrus. Very nice. Taste is tons of oak and sour funk, with lemon and grapefruit coming through and finishing with a satisfying dryness. Smooth, funky, and really tart, with great carbonation to keep it feeling good in the mouth. Will buy a bottle of this when Im lucky enough to see it in stores.

(750ml bottle blend 2 bottled 2-24-10) rich dark orange, very few bubbles. Nose of tart cherry, tangerine, wet wood, and funky. Taste is quite tart, cherry pipe tobacco, wet barrel, funky, tangerine, delicious. Nice tart linger, fruity and tobacco flavors. Slightly undercarbonated but doesnt detract at all. Nice beer!
Delicious. Probably the best Jolly Pumpkin Ive had. Honey and tart smell. Fruity flavor. Light vinegar. I could drink a whole big bottle.

Blend 2 bottled 2-24-10 thanks to thirdeye11.  Deep amber with a light cream head.  Nose is wood, light funk, tart, dried cherries, and buggy.  Great on the palate, nice tart flavor, wood, yeast, dried fruits, and bugs.

Pours a hazy brown almost an amber color with good head and some lace. The aroma is very funky with cheese horse blanket sour cherry and some bread. The flavor is very sour with some lemon peel and is well balanced with a good strawberry and fruity character. The beer is dry and oaky and has some vinous notes. Beautiful.

On tap at MBGSF 2010. Wonderful! Nice, sour taste, the sourest so far. Coming close to a Rodenbach GC in sourness, though a completely different beer. Great tang, a little lactic, yogurt, some caramel, lots of dark fruits.
On tap at MBGSF 2010. Really funky bretty. Pretty sour. Cherry. This may have had some variation from the original but Im not sure.

Served on draft at the Michigan Summer Beerfest, 2010, as part of RBSG festivities. Pours a hazy dark orange amber color with a thin head. Fair head retention and lacing. Tart aroma of cherries, peaches and an earthy funkiness. The taste is very tart cherries, apples, a bit of vinegar and lemon. Thin-medium bodied. Nice beer.

22 oz. bottle shared by STLWill- thanks again, Will.  Blend 02, bottled 2/24/10.  Pours a cloudy amber color with a small, fading beige head.  Aroma of lactic acid, raspberry, funk, caramel malts, and oak.  Flavor of raspberry, lactic acid, sour lemon, oak, tart apples, and mineral notes.  Light-bodied, with high carbonation and a tart mouthfeel.  Sour lemon finish.  Excellent.

Aroma is lactic, strawberry, lemon, funk, some caramel malts, 
Taste is insanely strawberry, lemon, funk, some crisp malts, and a touch of wheat is perceptible (although I am not sure whether or not this has wheat).  
Finish is slightly sour, a bit lactic, and lemon.
Very nice!

Bottle purchased at Sicilianos back in January. Clear reddish copper pour with a medium beige head. Nose of caramel malt and that very familiar JP sourness with a touch of citrus in there too. Funky and somewhat sour flavor with a caramel sweetness that appears before the tart finish.

Location: Bottle at Max and Andys Fantasy Tasting, 5/1/10


Aroma: The nose has some malt, booze, sour fruits, spice, and earth.

Appearance: It pours a a clear amber-golden color with a white head.

Flavor: The taste is some sweetness along with that JP sourness.

Palate: The palate on this one is a bit astringent, with an oak-like dryness and a nice drinkability. 

Overall Impression: 
This one has that typical Jolly Pumpkin feel to it that all of their beers seem to share.  Beyond that, it was just alright.  I liked it enough, but I dont think it quite deserves the high score that it has on here.  Anyway, decent stuff, Id drink it again, and maybe the next time I drink it I will think its worth the high praise.

Two sips and the sneezing began. These funky beers always destroy my allergies, yet I cant stop drinking it. Dido on what everyone else said about this beer. Not as sweet as I thought it would be, thank god!

Bottle (slight gusher). Murky brown pour little to no head. Aroma is quite funky, lots of brett, very woody, some small fruits (strawberry) and grain. Taste is slightly sour, lots of oak notes some fruity sweetness too. Very well balanced acidity, barrel aging and sweetness. Delicious.

Blend 2 bottled 2-24-10. Gusher. Murky glowing caramel color with fine fizzy head.  Aroma of caramel red apple, pear juice, spicy woody, brett, touch of metallic iron/blood but faint, some acedo/acedic, grape skins, has some Flemish red or American sour notes, maybe like consecration.  Wow, fairly sour, nice going, must have got a nice taste of oxygen, cherry, some light hints of iron, red caramel apple, subtle wood, softer classic JP clean quick finish with lingering cherry sourness.  Medium/light bodied, lightly round, fine fizzy carbonation. Delightful.

Bottle @ UDRM. Aged in french oak barrels. The aroma has citrus, , some raspberry, yeast, oak. Hazy, murky brown coloured beer with a thin head. The taste is a little sour, little sweet. It has oak, leather, yeast, fruitiness. This is a very good beer.

Bomber poured into a tulip.  Dark brown with ruby tinge, with fluffy off-white head that dissipates mostly, leaving a ring around the glass.  Aroma of tart apples, oak, bready yeast.  Taste is slightly sour, with sweet bready malt.  Mouthfeel is pretty light/medium and very crisply carbonated.  Quite quenching, a very nice beer!

Pours a clouded dirty bronze.  Aroma is apple, oak, pear, vanilla and funk.  Taste is spicey with some sweet florals and pepper coming through.  Medium mouthfeel that is very drinkable.  Finishes dry.

Bottle.  Aroma of sour fruits with musty bread.  Medium brown hazy hue with a small fully diminishing head that left no lace.  Flavor is sweet and tart with a nice dry earthy finish.  Palate is light-medium bodied and soft.  Very good beer.  Wonderful sour falvor and aroma with a great earthy balance.  Bravo!
Had this one @ Unofficial Dutch Ratebeer Meeting. Dark amber colored brew. Aroma is framboise, brett, oak. Flavor is light sour, yeast, framboise.

750 ml bottle, sticker on bottle says Blend 2, Bottled 2-24-10.  Served in a tulip glass, the beer pours a reddish/copper color with a half inch off-white head.  Head retention is low, not much lacing either.  Aroma is nice and tart, the brew smells like tart apples, vinegar, funk, cherries, and an earthy aroma.  It tastes pretty much just like the aroma, but with the addition of some oak, peppery spice and some grapes/red wine.  The tart/sour taste is the most noticable out of all the flavors, which is definitely a good thing for me!  Mouthfeel/body is medium, its a bit dry and has moderate carbonation.  Drinkability is good, its easy to drink and I enjoyed it.  Overall I think this is a good brew, its definitely worth a try.

Pours a slightly translucent burnt-umber with a surprisingly white head with no retention or lacing. 

Slightly sour nose, with tart raisins, pickled-peaches, dried cherries, slight hint of wood chips, and a tiny hint of vanilla. 

Tart but not sour taste, cranberries, vinegar-poached-cherries etc... dont get a lot of the oak, perhaps in the slight mellowing of the sourness. 

Palate is fairly crisp, but slightly sugary like home-made lemonade. Alcohol is understated, as is the carbonation.

Overall an interesting take on the style, I wish the oak played more heavily, would like to try it after some time in bottle.
UPDATED: NOV 29, 2015 Pours a hazy dark golden amber with fizzy head. Aromas of sour fruit, woody notes, and some funk. Flavors of vinegar, funk, and some dark fruit.  Dry finish and aftertaste.

750ml bottle.  Pours a hazy reddish brown with a small bubbly off white head.  Nice tart nose with dried citrus, barnyard and earth......some dry oak in there as well.  Fairly dry on the palate and very refreshing.  One of the better JP brews Ive had to date!

aroma is crunchy candy vinegar, rotten apple juice and prison pruno.  dirty socks and cheese.  appearance is a beautiful disaster, horrid murky mess far beyond hazy with a strangely perfect head atop it all.  flavor is spicy that ends quick and leads to inevitable sourness.  lemons rubbed in filth with more of the apple juice at the end.  the initial nose and mid taste reeks of a world class lambic, vinegar perfected.  quite dry end leaves the tongue ridden with cotton.  most interesting example of the substyle ive sampled as of yet, eternally drinkable.

Bottle syas oak aged, but this must be the one. Tasted @ UDRM, Oirschot. Oak, leather and lemon in the intense aroma. Vinous oaky flavor with caramel and even a bit of chocolate. The oak comes back stronger in the aftertaste. Great beer.

Bottle @ RB meeting Joes. A little hazy amber/copper colored beer, with a small beige head. The aroma is a little sour with fruits like raspberries. Some sweet in the back. The taste is fruity, some sour. Mostly raspberries with citrus. The aftertaste is bitter with some sweet fruits.

Pours hazy brown with slight purple highlights and dense tan head.  Sour and fruity aroma of cherries, citrus, some woodiness, and plum.  Flavor is sour but clearly picks up some woody notes from the aging process.  Somewhat mellow and subdued, the beer earns points for its subtle bouquet of dark fruit flavors, restrained usage of of barrel aging, and slight bitter edge.  A solid offering.
Brown/black color with off white head.  Sour, yeasty nose, sour palate with a  red wine finish.  Nice

Bottle at Dutch RB meeting, thanks for sharing joes! Pours a hazy copper to amber color with a thin off-white head. Aroma is brett with raspberry and more fruits. Flavor is sour and sweet in a very nice balance. A slight hint of bitterness in the finish completes an excellent brew.

The pour was cloudy and brown with an ample off-white head.  The aroma was a touch of sour fruit, light funk and plenty of spice.  The flavor was also predominately spicy with some funk and sourness coming through from time to time.  A relatively thin body that was fairly dry.  I was a bit underwhelmed with this offering.

UPDATED: APR 3, 2010 750 mL bottle.  Foams over a bit when opened.  Pours lightly hazed copper color with a head that dissolves immediately (a later, very vigorous pour creates a head that sticks around for a while).  Aroma of sweet and tart apple juice along with light berry.  Flavor has the tart apple, fairly dry, and bits of woody and red fruit notes.  Some bretty funky notes are especially apparent in the finish.  Delicious.

Pours out a mostly clear copper color with a small lacing white head. Aroma is funky with some citrus, light cherry and some wood lingering in there somewhere. Taste is complex with some nice notes of sour cherry, barnyard funk, oak and a nice, but never overpowering tartness. Definitely solid.

Bottled. Cloudy brown pour, dense, light tan head. Nose is sour with a hint of brett mustiness, barnyard, cherries, apples. Flavor is tart, vinous, oaky, barnyeard, lemongrass, and spice. Bitter herbal finish, tart and refreshing. Excellent.

[Bottle] purchased at Healthy Spirits. Pours a clear caramel with ruby highlights and a finger of fluffy tan head. Aroma is strongly acetic and lactic, lots of oak and barrel character, tannin, and sour cherry. Flavor is slightly watery, lightly bitter, and not as complex as the aroma. Oaky, slightly sour, acetic, and lots of apple. The flavor was a bit disappointing after the awesome aroma.
Bottle in sommerhus. Pours a clear reddish brown. Mellow sourness and slightly tart. Aromas of berries with hints of metals. Medium bodied. Sour and bitter finish. Tastes more like a Flemmish sour.

Batch 256

A: Pours an amberish brown with a small off white head. No real retention or lace noted.

S: Funky sour aroma with some dark fruit noted. The oak stands out as well with hints of red wine.

T: Tart green apple flavors that seem to yield to tart dark fruit with hints of cherry. There are mild caramel undertones with a nice blast of oak.

M: Medium in body, lighter carbonation.
Pours reddish brown with a beige head. Aroma is malt, sour, light oak and leather. Flavour is malt, sour, redwine, light oak, vanilla and brett.

batch#256
pours reddish, dark brown, off-white head.
aroma, oak, yeasty, fruity; white grape with the wood coming across nicely.
flavor, wood oak, light spicy palate, white grapes and yeasty mouthfeel The beer retains a certain smoothness and some tartness.
Tasty beer, love the mix of the oak and the spices that come out of it added with the overall sour feel of the beer while keeping the biere de garde profile.

750 ml bottle - thanks to RCL for the trade; batch 346/348; slight haze, chestnut brown; fluffy tan head; musky, oaky aromas with cherries, dark fruit and obvious tartness; texture is thin and drinks with a mild zing; yeasty spice, fruity tartness, smooth dark fruits with almost a touch of chocolate too; mouth feel is kind of fizzy; mild spice and tartness; not quite my cup of tee but interesting nevertheless

Mahogany, long lasting beige head, excellent lacing. Aroma is herbal, slightly sour, woody, underlying sweetness. Flavour is quite sour, fruity, tart and dry, quite smooth as well. Sour mouth, med body, high carb. Finishes long, funky, fruity, sour and tart.  Nice stuff, good funk in this. JP is quickly rising up the list of my favorite American breweries.  750ml bottle obtained in a trade with TheCheeseMan, thanks Dan. Opened on May 28, 2009. Batch #256.

Botella. Clear red-brown colour with a medium off-white head. Quite pleasant sour spiced woody very malty caramel aroma.  Good mouthfeel.  is moderate to heavy malty, caramel, berry, grape, red wine, Sweet sour flavor with berries, some spice, a good maltiness and wood.

(bottle shared by MatSciGuy) Pours a solid amber with a medium off-white head that doesnt last.  The aroma is very strong, with a lot of oak, apple skin, apple cinnamon muffins, and some dust.  The flavor isnt nearly as strong or tart as the aroma had led me to believe, with some subdued flavors of apple cider, caramel, that ends with a pleasant oaky finish.  Mouthfeel is medium with fairly lively carbonation.  Pretty good right now, but I could see it getting better with some age.

batch 367/368
clear dark amber, almost red-wine brown/red. small flim white smooth head. sour and fresh berries in the aroma, perhaps some faint wood too. great aroma. flavor is bertty, a little sour, some wood, well blended and mellow. a little too bretty to hit home with me, but a nice sour it is.
Clear amber with a large beige head. Sourish aroma with roasted malt with, lacto and caramel notes. Sour flavour with roasted malt, caramel and lacto notes. Finished sour.

Bottle 75cl. @ home.Clear medium red amber color with a average to large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, caramel, berry, grape, red wine, wood - oak, light alcohol. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and moderate bitter with a average to long duration, and aa dry finish. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20090811]

Bottle. Aroma is mildly funky with strong fruit tones. Amber with a medium head. Flavor is simple, very much subdued barnyard character. Fairly thick and engulfing palate. This lacks the depth expected from JP, but is nonetheless highly enjoyable.
Bottle. Pours a dark amber color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity spicy slightly tart aroma. Fruity malty spicy flavor with some tart sour hints. Has a fruity spicy and slightly tart finish.

Bottle, 50cl. Pours a brown beer with an offwhite head. The aroma is caramel with some acidity. The flavor is likewise acidity. The palate is thin. Overall the beer is fresh but could use some body. Not my type of beer.

very tart sour acid nose, lacy brown mirky body, flavor is quite tart and very well soured, yet not so sour that its difficult to enjoy, tastes like dried out citrus rind, bitter and acidic, but it tastes like its good for me, oak flavors are hard to place, very tart and very enjoyable, I find many sours this tart to be quite watery but this has a much more substantial mouthfeel

Deep ruby pour with a frothy white head.  The color contrast looks gorgeous.  Nose has layers of tart cherry, fresh wood, and a bit of wholesome barnyard funk.  Flavor is bursting with tartness but is beautifully balanced by an amazing dried/preserved strawberry sweetness that I just cannot get enough of.  Exceedingly smooth and drinkable, as the abv is spot on.  Definitely my favorite from Jolly Pumpkin so far ... no contest.
750ml bottle at Sylvains tasting. Nice candy tartness. Fruity brett and quite sweet. Quite funky and barnyard. Not very acidic and vinous. This is right on my tastes ! Need to have it again.
Pours deep amber into a tulip.  Off-white head recedes to skim surface. Sour pit fruit and funky yeast aromas. Full and sour cherry. Lasting tart finish.

750ml bottle with a very cool label depicting the wind blowing a ship around. This beer was an opaque red color with a thin white head resting across the top. The smell was really good and made me think of fruit, especially cherries. The taste was cherries, tart, sour, but not overpowering.Im not sure I tasted the oak. I especially liked the mouthfeel as the carbonation seemed bubbly and perfect for this beer. This beer just got better and better as it warmed. I have been consistently impressed by the Jolly Pumpkin beers and I am glad they came to Colorado. This beer was excellent and worth the price of admission.

05/10/08 batch 256

I was a little disappointed that the price went up to $14.99 but since this is my favorite JP beer I caved. This was every bit as good as I remembered from last year. Tart smell, nice sour cherry flavor, some oak this time, the sourness is perfect. This is so easy to drink and a wonderful beer. Still my favorite from JP.

01/25/09 2007 bottle thanks to moejuck

Smells acidic like tomatos or ketchup, slight bit of oak and funk, smells really good. Tart but not sour, very easy to drink, subtle flavors, might be better fresh but it holds up well after 20 months or so.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 06-06-2007 14:55:19

Deep ruby brown with  generous carbonation and slow  foamy legs.  Pleasantly sour aroma, reminiscent of both lemons  and limes.  Sour overall taste, with most powerful onset, and understated, refreshingly tart aftertaste.  Sourness, and citrus flavors disguise both malts and alcohol, with a slight twinge of sulphur.  鶚/348) enjoyed on 8.9.09

They had bottles of this at the hop cat and I didnt mind dropping 17 bucks on one. Dark amber pour with white head. Aroma of jolly pumpkin funk, apples, crackers, bread. A bit spicey and woody. Flavor is stunning. Sour and tart, fruity. Lots of notes of cherry, apple, and other fruits. Drank a whole 750 of this and still wanted more. The best beer of the night by far.

UPDATED: SEP 6, 2009 Bottle from Knightly.  Why did I wait this long to pick up a bottle?  Pours a dark amber color with a nice fluffy head.  Good retention the whole way through.  The aroma shows flowers, brett, apples, and a lesser dark fruit scent.  Flavors are nicely tart and sour with apples, pears and cherries.  Lots of brett and very dry in the finish.  Everything meshes really well here.  YUM, this is delicous!  A little expensive, yeah, but I want more!

Pours dark amber brown with a decent beige head.  Smells of sour apple bubble gum and spiced malt.  Tastes like sour apples, sour grape, some smoked wood, some spice, slightly citrusy, tart, very acidic. White wine-like dry finsh.   This is the first beer of this style that I have tryed and it is overwhelmingly good.  Its not like anything Ive tried.  Very complex and very unusual.  Awesome.

Bottle @ Cervezageek - smagning, Odense. Batch 346/348. Pours clear dark amber with a small creamy white head. Super complex nose. Oak, tart, fresh, brett, fruit. Smooth and crisp. Nuts and caramel flavor with brett tickling the cheek. Ends dry. Nice
Slightly hazy chestnut with a lasting off-white head. Aroma of wine barrel, vanilla and caramel, with a little horse-blanket brett. Dry and tart, with cherry notes and brett and quite complex oak.

75 cL bottle. Pours dark brown with a short lasting tan head. Aroma is sour, fruity and slight wooden to sulphorish. That sourness in Jolly Pumpkin beers really remind me about infections rather than complex wild brett fermentation. Fruity, sulphorish and slight wooden flavoured. Vague peppery and yeasty flavoured. Hint of cherry like notes. Dry, mild sulphorish and acidic finish.
